In this study, we established a comprehensive reference of DNA methylation classes in acute leukemia and developed a machine learning classifier for methylation-based diagnostics in the clinic. Our approach offers several key features to complement conventional methods. First, when coupling MARLIN to nanopore sequencing, results can be generated rapidly and in real-time, setting a realistic timeframe of hours or even minutes for generating preliminary molecular classifications. Providing this information to pathologists and treating clinicians could greatly accelerate treatment planning and potentially limit the development of oncologic emergencies caused by treatment delays. Second, methylation-based classification may resolve blind spots of conventional molecular diagnostic and cytogenetic testing, including classes associated with cryptic rearrangements (for example, DUX4-r) or molecular drivers of lineage-ambiguous cases (for example, MPAL with BCL11B activation)67. Third, methylation-based profiling may reveal novel predictive signatures of drug response. For example, methylation-based classification can identify HOX-activated subgroups directly regardless of genetic driver, although whether this predicts sensitivity to menin inhibition requires further study. Finally, nanopore sequencing and MARLIN are comparably easy to implement, making our approach suitable even in lower-resourced clinical settings where molecular diagnostic services and hematopathology expertise are difficult to access. Ultimately, we envision methylation-based acute leukemia classifications complementing standard-of-care diagnostic tests to provide more comprehensive and timely information to pathologists, clinicians and patients.

We acknowledge several limitations to our work. Although we built our methylation reference on large public datasets to ensure broad representation, it is possible that there are insufficient sample numbers for uncommon acute leukemia subtypes to discover associated methylation classes. Consequently, we envision that our current methylation reference and the MARLIN classifier will evolve in future iterations, reflecting improvements in knowledge and the availability of reference datasets. Although inclusive of most acute leukemia subtypes encountered in clinical practice, the current training set does not include entities that could reasonably enter into the clinical differential diagnosis with acute leukemia (such as MDS, myeloproliferative neoplasms or high-grade B cell lymphomas), and it also does not include post-treatment and/or relapse samples. Thus, MARLIN-based classifications should be considered in the context of orthogonal clinical and pathology data to determine whether a sample has met conventional diagnostic criteria for acute leukemia versus other entities. Finally, although our study includes one of the largest published nanopore sequencing cohorts of acute leukemia to date, it has a modest size compared to other studies assessing novel diagnostic approaches in the field of acute leukemia68. Therefore, future studies will be required to better assess MARLIN's performance with nanopore sequencing across a broader representation of subtypes and to define limitations from possible confounders such as low tumor-cell content. These studies will also provide an opportunity to specify how epigenetic classification should be used to maximize its clinical utility.

In summary, we propose a comprehensive framework for rapid classification of acute leukemia in the clinic using epigenetics, nanopore sequencing and real-time data analysis with a machine learning classifier adapted to sparse data. We believe that our framework has potential for clinical, translational and basic research applications and paves the way for future developments in epigenetic classification of acute leukemia and machine learning-assisted diagnostics.

The acute leukemia DNA methylation reference cohort was built from publicly available datasets comprising Illumina Infinium Methylation 450k and EPIC arrays. Raw IDAT files were downloaded from the public repositories listed in the Data availability section of this manuscript. A complete list of samples used in this study is provided in Supplementary Table 1. All included samples were collected from patients at the time of diagnosis.

Annotations were retrieved from the respective publications for GSE147667 (ref. 28), GSE152710 (ref. 34), GSE159907 (ref. 27), TCGA-LAML32 and TARGET-ALL-P3 (ref. 33). For GSE49031, annotations were supplemented with updated annotations from additional publications22,38. For GSE159907, annotations were supplemented with data from the Beat AML project[31]. For TARGET AML, annotations were harmonized between annotations from four different publications30,69,70,71. Annotations were retrieved from additional publications for KMT2A-PTD32,47,71,72, UBTF-ITD53,71, HNRNPH1::ERG confirmed cases73 and BCL11B status47,67. For all publications, fusion information for common alterations was harmonized between published RNA-sequencing results and published information from conventional assays (for example, karyotyping, FISH). However, as many fusion events are cryptic, we only considered patients with negative RNA-sequencing results as confirmed negative. FLT3 activating mutations were filtered according to the list provided in a previous publication74. Established methylation class annotations for T-ALL and AML were kindly provided by the respective study authors27,28.

Raw IDAT files were read into R (v.4.4.0) using minfi's (v.1.50.0) read.metharray function75. For every sample, chipwide medians of the methylated and unmethylated channels were retrieved using minfi's getQC function, and a sample cutoff of ≥10.5 for log2 median meth/unmeth signal intensity was chosen for sample inclusion. In addition, detection P values were retrieved using minfi's detectionP function, and a per-sample cutoff was chosen at a mean detection P value of <0.01 for all measured probes. The minfi quality control report was generated and carefully inspected for every sample. All samples that did not pass one of the quality control metrics were removed. Sample normalization was performed using the ‘ssNoob' method. Probes that were not shared between both versions of the array, RS, CH, non-uniquely mapping and single-nucleotide polymorphism probes were removed. In addition, all probes that had a detection P value of greater than 1 × 10−16 in any of the high-quality samples were removed. Preprocessing was performed separately for each dataset, and the Mset objects were combined using the combineArrays function before being converted to beta values using the getBeta function. The final beta matrix contained 2,540 samples and 207,057 probes. To extend the number of probes available for MARLIN, only probes that were not on all of the most recent versions of the array (450k, EPIC, EPICv2), RS, CH, non-uniquely mapping and single-nucleotide polymorphism probes were removed, resulting in 357,340 final probes.

For t-SNE dimensionality reduction, we used the 5,000 most variable probes within samples diagnosed as B-ALL, T-ALL and AML to construct a weighted correlation matrix (weights package in R (v.1.0.4)). The corresponding distance matrix was used as input for t-SNE performed using the Rtsne package (v.1.0.4). The ggplot2 R package (v.3.5.1) was used for plotting. Genome-wide copy-number profiles were generated using the conumee2 package (v.2.0.2)76.

Most methylation classes were adopted directly or with minor adjustments from three previous studies that focused on AML (13 classes)27, T-ALL (five classes)28 and B-ALL (seven classes)38, respectively (Extended Data Fig. 1c). B-ALL sample labels were based on International Consensus Classification categories38. To better reflect observations in the methylation space or account for inadequate sample sizes in certain groups, four B-ALL methylation classes were derived by splitting or merging established categories22,24. ETV6::RUNX1 and ETV6::RUNX1-like were merged to form one methylation class, ‘ETV6::RUNX1'. TCF3::PBX1 and MEF2D-r were combined. In addition, BCR::ABL1, BCR::ABL1-like and CRLF2-r (excluding PAX5alt with CRLF2-r) samples were clustered based on their 1,000 most variable probes and split into two classes (Ph/Ph-like and CRLF2-r/Ph-like; Extended Data Fig. 1d). Similarly, PAX5alt and PAX5 P80R samples were split into PAX5 group A and PAX5 group B (Extended Data Fig. 1e). Furthermore, we observed several patient groups without a corresponding methylation class. This was particularly pronounced among patients with pediatric AML alterations. New methylation classes were defined for the genetic alterations ETV6::MNX1 (ETV6::MNX1), FUS::ERG/FUS::FEV (FUS-r), HNRNPH1::ERG (HNRNPH1::ERG), CBFA2T3::GLIS2 (GLIS-r) and KAT6A::CREBBP/KAT6A::EP300 (HOXA-activated group 6, KAT6A-r). We also established an ‘AMKL-mixed' class encompassing AMKL cases with diverse genetic alterations. This class was originally defined based on samples with FAB M7 morphology harboring NUP98::KDM5A or RBM15::MKL1 fusions. We defined two classes representing KMT2A-r infant AML (HOXA-activated group 8 + 9). Initial class labels were defined by hierarchical clustering of infant KMT2A-r AML (age <3 years) with FAB M4 and M5 morphology, excluding KMT2A-r with MLLT10 and MLLT3, as those fusions were commonly found in other classes (Extended Data Fig. 1f). We defined the class of BCL11B-activated lineage-ambiguous leukemia based on sample labels in previous work67. Lastly, we defined five control classes.

Through the steps described above, we could define labels for 1,346 out of 2,540 samples (53.0%; Extended Data Fig. 1g). We used a semi-supervised clustering strategy to assign labels to the remaining samples, which were either not considered in the original studies or did not have complete metadata available. To generate stable consensus labels, we performed semi-supervised clustering 100 times on randomly subsampled parts of our dataset (Extended Data Fig. 1h). For this purpose, we randomly chose 80% of samples with and without labels. To ensure that we did not rely too heavily on existing labels, we also randomly masked 20% of all samples with labels in each iteration. We then calculated the weighted Pearson's correlation coefficients for these samples. We did this separately for each iteration using the 4,000 most variable AML, B-ALL and T-ALL probes and the 1,500 most variable global probes. The weight was the standard deviation per probe. In the next step, we constructed a graph with edges to the four closest neighbors. Finally, label propagation was performed according to previous work77 as implemented in the igraph R package (v.2.0.3). After 100 iterations, we assigned consensus labels to all 2,540 samples (Extended Data Fig. 1i,j). To ensure that we would not use samples that may be impure, we first excluded all samples that were assigned to a control class in more than 30% of cases (117 out of 2,540 samples; 4.6%). All samples with the same class or class family in more than 70% of iterations were assigned the class or majority class if in a class family (2,356 out of 2,540; 92.8%). All remaining samples were not assigned a class (67 out of 2,540; 2.6%).

RNAseq data were retrieved from the Genomic Data Commons (https://gdc.cancer.gov) for TARGET AML, Beat AML, TARGET-ALL-P3 and TCGA-LAML. We extracted unstranded count data of protein-coding genes. Data were previously processed according to the standardized GDC pipeline https://docs.gdc.cancer.gov/Data/Bioinformatics_Pipelines/Expression_mRNA_Pipeline). Counts were transformed to VST values using the vst function implemented in the DESeq2 R package (v.1.44.0)78. Z-score scaling was performed on all samples within AML methylation classes for visualization of single gene expression. Differential expression analysis was performed only on the TARGET AML data using the standard DESeq2 R pipeline.

MARLIN is a neural network able to process multi-platform and sparse methylation data trained in R (v.4.1.3) using the keras (v.2.13.0) and data.table (v.1.14.2) packages. The model architecture is composed of three fully connected layers. The first two layers have 256 and 128 nodes, respectively, with sigmoid activation. The first layer has an input size of 357,340, equal to the number of high-quality CpG sites of the reference cohort. The final layer is composed of 42 nodes, representing the 42 methylation classes. The control classes of peripheral blood adults and pediatric were merged into one control class to allow the model to learn general peripheral blood methylation patterns rather than age-specific ones. Softmax activation was chosen for this layer, and the scores (which sum up to 1) represent the class probabilities. During the training phases, a dropout rate of 0.99 was applied to the input layer within each epoch, defined as one complete pass of the entire training dataset. Categorical cross-entropy was used as a multiclass classification loss function. Beta values of the methylation array cohort were binarized to −1 and +1 with a beta value cutoff of 0.5, similar to previous works18,19,61. The model was trained using 50 randomly selected samples per methylation class (with replacement) for 3,000 epochs with a batch size of 32, a learning rate of 10−5 and the Adam optimizer. The model was trained using a Nvidia A100 80 GB GPU.

To evaluate MARLIN performance, fivefold cross-validation was performed. Samples were randomly divided into training (four folds) and test set (one fold). For each training set, 50 randomly selected samples for each class were used to train the model. Data sparsity was simulated on the test fold, converting an increasing fraction of CpGs to zero (from 0% to 100% in 1% increments, essentially setting them to ‘NA'). The F1 scores, defined as the harmonic mean of precision and recall, were used to evaluate the model. The final training was performed with the entire dataset, randomly sampling 50 observations for each class.

External validation cohorts were composed of methylation profiles obtained with different technologies, including Illumina Infinium Methylation 27k and 450k arrays, whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and nanopore26,29,30,35,63,64,65,66. Processed data were downloaded from GEO accessions GSE152136, GSE213685, GSE155339, GSE133986 and GSE56600, EBI ArrayExpress accessions E-GEOD-35069 and E-MTAB-10090 and the Genomic Data Commons data repository (TARGET AML). Methylation values were binarized (−1 and +1) and restricted to the CpG positions used for training our model. Missing values were set to zero.

To determine an optimal classification threshold, we performed a receiver operating characteristic analysis of the maximum MARLIN prediction scores calculated during cross-validation. Samples correctly classified were labeled as ‘classified'; otherwise, as ‘misclassified'. We defined the optimal threshold by maximizing the Youden index (specificity + sensitivity − 1). At a simulated sparsity level of 97%, up to which the performance of our model remains stable, we found that a cutoff of 0.83 maximizes the Youden index with a specificity of 90.8% and sensitivity of 79.7%. At lower levels of sparsity (higher sequencing coverage), we found similar performances with higher optimal thresholds (for example, at 95% sparsity, the optimal cutoff was 0.93 with a specificity of 90.4% and sensitivity of 80.6%). At higher levels of sparsity levels, optimal thresholds and area under the curve dramatically decreased, in line with our previous performance analysis. We therefore reasoned that a cutoff of 0.8 is an adequate threshold for variable sequencing depths.

In a subset of cases, a predicted sample may fall between biologically similar classes, in which case MARLIN may not reach the classification threshold for an individual class. We reasoned that predictions contain valuable information; for example, by distinguishing these cases from other, more readily distinguishable methylation classes. Hence, we introduced methylation class families as a post-prediction step in which scores for individual methylation classes within a family are summed to yield a single score. Definitions of methylation class families are included in Supplementary Table 2. Methylation class families were also included in cross-validation analysis.

A cohort of 34 bone marrow aspirate, peripheral blood or pericardial fluid samples from 34 distinct patients (19 female, 14 male; median age: 61.5 years) was selected from the Center for Advanced Molecular Diagnosis at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI). The cohort included 20 AML samples, 11 B-ALL samples, one T-ALL sample, one MPAL sample and one essential thrombocythaemia sample by genetic classification following the WHO Classification of Tumors of the Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tissues (4th edition). We did not use the 4th edition provisional entity ‘AML with RUNX1 mutation', as it has been removed from recent classification schemes, and instead classified those cases as ‘AML with myelodysplasia-related changes'. In addition, six MDS cases were included in our cohort. All patients provided written informed consent to the DFCI Institutional Review Board-approved research protocol 01-206 for ‘Tissue and Data Collection for Research Studies in Patients with Hematologic Malignancies, Bone Marrow Disorders and Normal Donors'. To ensure data protection, all patients were assigned a unique numerical identifier for research purposes. The demographic characteristics of the patient cohort are provided in Supplementary Table 11 and Supplementary Table 16. In total, ten healthy donor controls were sequenced; four gDNA samples from bone marrow aspirates and six K2EDTA-anticoagulated peripheral blood samples obtained from BioIVT, provided with consent under their respective sponsor's protocol number (Supplementary Table 15). Finally, all samples were later subjected to Oxford Nanopore Technologies library preparation and sequencing.

Freshly collected bone marrow and peripheral blood samples were processed to obtain DNA. DNA was extracted using the Qiagen DNeasy Blood and Tissue DNA extraction kit (cat. no 69506), following the manufacturer's instructions for non-nucleated blood specimens. For every patient sample retrieved, 150–200 μl of specimen was mixed with 20 μl of proteinase K, adjusting the volume to 220 μl with PBS. Then, 200 μl of ALT lysis buffer was added, and samples were gently vortexed. To complete the cell lysis step, samples were incubated for 10 min at 56 °C. For DNA precipitation, 200 μl of 100% ethanol was added to the samples. This mixture was then placed into a mini column and centrifuged for 1 min at 8,000 rpm. The mini column was placed into a new collection tube, and a first washing step was performed by adding 500 μl of buffer AW1 and centrifuging for 1 min at 8,000 rpm. The collection tube was discarded, and a second washing step was done using 500 μl of AW2 buffer, centrifuging for 3 min at 14,000 rpm. Finally, the DNA was eluted from the column by adding 200 μl of elution buffer and centrifuging for 1 min at 8,000 rpm. The elution step was repeated several times to increase DNA recovery, and DNA quantification was done using the Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific, cat. no. Q33238).

To make samples suitable for a sequencing run, 500 ng to 1 μg of DNA from 19 patients were prepared using the Ligation Sequencing Kit V14 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies, cat. no. SQK-LSK114). All samples were prepared according to the manufacturer's instructions, following an increased AMPureXP incubation period up to 30 min in both end-repair and ligation reactions and a two-in-a-row elution step for 30 min each. After end-repair bead incubation and ethanol washing, beads were allowed to dry for 5 min. After the ligation step, bead incubation and long-fragment buffer washing, the beads were dried for 15 min. DNA was eluted in 16–18 μl of nuclease-free water. The abundance of the DNA recovered after the library preparation was quantified using the Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific, cat. no. Q33238), and DNA size was assessed in some specimens with the TapeStation system (Agilent Technologies, cat. no. G2992AA) to corroborate the existence of high molecular weight DNA to obtain long reads. In the expanded cohort, 15 additional samples were processed using the Rapid Barcoding Kit 24 V14 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies, cat. no. SQK-RBK114.24), according to the manufacturer's instructions. We prepared two multiplexed libraries, each one including eight and seven patients' samples, respectively, of the total additional cases.

Once the libraries were prepared, they were loaded either on a MinION flow cell device (Oxford Nanopore Technologies, cat. no. FLO-MIN114 R.10.4.1) or, for select samples, on PromethION flow cells for detection of structural variants, single-nucleotide variants and indels (cat. no. FLO-PRO114M R.10.4.1) (Supplementary Table 12). Flow cells priming and library loading steps were performed using the Flow Cell Priming Kit (cat. no. EXP-FLP004) according to the manufacturer's instructions. All libraries were sequenced for 48–72 h, depending on the number of pores remaining and the reads generated by both times. Once the sequencing run was finished, library DNA was pulled out to perform a washing step, adding 398 μl of washing buffer and 2 μl of washing mix into the flow cell for 1 h according to protocol (EXP-WSH004). The washing fluid was then removed, and the flow cell was again primed with 1,170 μl of flow cell flush and 30 μl of flow cell tether. Libraries were again loaded onto the flow cell spotON port, and the sequencing run was restarted.

Pod5 raw data files were processed using Dorado (v.0.3.2), with a minimum q-score of 10 and using the human genome assemblies hg19 and T2T (processed with a Nvidia A100 80 GB GPU). The high-accuracy model used for base and modified base calling was selected according to the kit chemistry versions. Methylation calls were extracted from BAM files using the modkit tool (v.0.1.13), which produced a BED file restricted to CpG positions of our reference cohort and containing the methylation status of covered CpGs. Total number of reads, genome-wide called CpGs, covered array-based reference CpGs, average 5mC and 5hmC were calculated for quality assessment Supplementary Table 12. Methylation calls were binarized as described above and used as input for MARLIN. Prediction scores are reported in Supplementary Table 13. Maximum score and a threshold of 0.8 were used to evaluate the results. Prediction scores for 42 individual methylation classes were also aggregated at the methylation class family and lineage levels. A custom R script was used to extract read IDs and timestamps to simulate real-time predictions. BED files with the binarized methylation calls were generated for every 5 min of sequencing. Predictions were produced using the combined data up to that point. Methylation calls for retrospective (n = 34) and prospective (n = 5) samples are accessible on GEO (GSE280090). Two files are provided for each sample: one file containing the methylation calls of CpGs restricted to positions of probes in our reference, and one file containing genome-wide methylation calls for 5mC and 5hmC in bedMethyl format.

To confirm suspected structural variants in high-coverage nanopore data obtained from PromethION sequencing runs, we first extracted read IDs for all reads mapping to involved genes using Samtools (v.1.20). We then intersected lists of read IDs to identify split reads mapping to both fusion gene partners (for example, RUNX1 and RUNX1T1 or PML and RARA). For the DUX4 rearrangement, we extracted all IDs of reads mapping to the D4Z4 repeat array on chromosome 4q35 containing a number of DUX4 genes or pseudogenes and overlapped read IDs with reads mapping to the immunoglobulin heavy locus on chromosome 14. Split reads were pulled out from the BAM files using Samtools and visualized with IGV browser (v.2.7.14) using the Region Navigator.

For the five real-time classification samples, DNA was extracted as described above. DNA was then prepared using either the Rapid Sequencing Kit V14 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies, cat. no. LSK-RAD114) for rapid analysis or the Ligation Sequencing Kit V14 (cat. no. LSK-SQK114) for later, deeper sequencing. For all patients, DNA size was checked using the TapeStation system (Agilent Technologies, cat. no. G2992AA). Nanopore sequencing was performed on a MinION flow cell (cat. no. FLO-MIN114 R.10.4.1), with active base calling, methylation calling in the context of 5mC and 5hmC and real-time alignment to the hg19 human genome, allowing a BAM file generation every 10 min. These processes were handled using MinKNOW software (v.24.02.16) in a GridION platform with accelerated computing integrated (Nvidia Quadro GV100 GPU). The BAM files with the methylation calls were produced every 10 min. A custom bash script was used to check whether new BAM files were generated every 5 s. If so, methylation calls were extracted from the new BAM file using the modkit tool (v.0.1.13). The output was a BED file restricted to the CpG positions of our reference cohort and containing the methylation status of the covered CpGs. Custom R scripts were used to aggregate the BED files produced up to that time point, binarize the methylation calls, load MARLIN to generate the prediction, write a text file containing the prediction scores for each class, a timestamp and the number of covered CpGs and to plot the classification results at the class, methylation class family and lineage level. A single prospective sample (RTC_003) briefly received a MARLIN prediction score above the classification threshold before changing towards a related methylation class upon deeper sequencing. We therefore recommend monitoring real-time MARLIN scores until predictions stabilize. The real-time classification script is available on GitHub (https://github.com/hovestadt/MARLIN).

All patient samples were diagnosed using gold standard diagnosis techniques at the DFCI, including targeted sequencing by DFCI's rapid heme panel (RHPv3)79, which uses next-generation sequencing to search for alterations in 95 genes that are frequently associated with leukemias, bone marrow aspirate, immunohistochemistry staining, cytogenetics and flow cytometry.

No statistical methods were used to predetermine sample size. For the reference cohort, inclusion was based on availability of high-quality public data. The experiments were not randomized and investigators were not blinded to allocation during experiments and outcome assessment, as grouping is based on the molecular characteristics of individual patients. For the retrospective and prospective nanopore sequencing cohorts, samples were selected based on availability and with the aim of covering a broad spectrum of molecular subtypes. No data were excluded. Select samples were resequenced using the PromethION nanopore instrument to detect underlying genetic events (AL_02, AL_10, AL_24) or to test real-time implementation of MARLIN (AL_16). No allocation of samples into experimental groups occurred. All patient data collection and pathological analyses were performed independently of this study as part of routine clinical procedures. Results from MARLIN predictions on clinical samples were not used by pathologists or providers for patient care. Statistical tests used are reported in the figure legends.

Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.

Methylation calls from nanopore sequencing are available at the GEO under accession number GSE280090. Previously published methylation array datasets were downloaded from GEO under accession numbers GSE147667 (ref. 28) (n = 135), GSE152710 (ref. 34) (n = 10), GSE159907 (refs. 27,31) (n = 278), GSE49031 (ref. 22) (n = 811) and GSE87571 (ref. 35) (n = 20); the EBI ArrayExpress platform under accession E-MTAB-12551 (ref. 37) (n = 7) and E-MTAB-7069 (ref. 36) (n = 22); or the Genomic Data Commons data repository (TCGA-LAML32 (n = 193)). The data generated by the TARGET initiative were downloaded from GEO under accession numbers GSE124413 (TARGET0531 (ref. 30) (n = 441)) and GSE1909311 (TARGET1031 (ref. 80) (n = 428)) or from the NCI Genomic Data Commons (selecting patients from TARGET0531 (ref. 30) (n = 106) and TARGET-ALL-P3 (ref. 33) (n = 89) cohorts). TARGET AML files are also available from dbGaP under study ID phs000465. More information about the TARGET initiative can be found at https://www.cancer.gov/ccg/research/genome-sequencing/target. Source data are provided with this paper.

Code for training and applying the MARLIN classifier is available on GitHub (https://github.com/hovestadt/MARLIN) and on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15723932)81 An open-access web application of the MARLIN classifier is available on shinyapps.io (https://hovestadtlab.shinyapps.io/shinyMARLIN). The MARLIN model (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15565404)82 and the processed training dataset (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15566584)83 are also available on Zenodo.

Over 100 iterations, the algorithm's four key steps (i) subsampling, (ii) construction of correlation matrix, (iii) graph construction from correlation matrix, and (iv) label propagation are repeated. i. Bar plots showing the percentual class assignment for each sample over the 100 iterations (top). a. Stacked bar plots showing lineage concordance by lineage (left), dataset (middle) and age group (right). Fractions are colored by immunophenotype with concordant and discordant cases colored separately. b. Visualization of lineage discordant cases. Out of the 60 lineage discordant cases, 49 were in the methylation classes ZNF384-r B-ALL (n = 4), HOXA9-activated T-ALL (n = 23), BCL11B-activated ALAL (n = 17), KMT2A-r B-ALL (n = 5). Sankey plots compare diagnosed immunophenotypes and study within those four methylation classes. We found that the lineage discordance was across a broad range of immunophenotypes and studies for the four classes. Highlighting that lineage discordance is not due to isolated studies, and that methylation patterns are robust between independent studies. c. Pie charts showing genetics of lineage discordant cases inside ZNF384-r, HOXA9-activated T-ALL, BCL11B-activated, and KMT2A-r B-ALL classes. We found characteristic lineage ambiguous alterations inside each class, including ZNF384-r (n = 3, methylation class ZNF384-r), PICALM::MLLT10 (n = 10, methylation class HOXA9-activated T-ALL), BCL11B (n = 6, methylation class BCL11B-activated), and KMT2A-r (n = 4, methylation class KMT2A-r B-ALL). d. Visualization of lineage ambiguous genetics specific to methylation classes. The top part shows all samples with known ZNF384-r, PICALM::MLLT10, BCL11B alteration, and KMT2A-r visualized on the t-SNE from Fig. 1a. The bottom part compares methylation class (rows) to immunophenotype (columns). We found that ZNF384-r, PICALM::MLLT10, and BCL11B are specific to the methylation classes ZNF384-r, HOXA9-activated T-ALL, and BCL11B-activated. Contrarily, KMT2A-r are genetic alterations that occur in several methylation classes across lineages. e. For cases within the BCL11B-activated methylation class, we wanted to see if we could verify their status as BCL11B-activated leukemia. Therefore, we first looked for BCL11B enhancer tandem amplification (BETA) in the copy-number profile of newly classified patients in the methylation class BCL11B-activated. BETA is a characteristic genetic event occurring in about 20% of BCL11B-activated leukemia67. We could confirm BETAs in 2/13 newly classified patients (15.4%). f. Comparison of BCL11B gene expression between AML, B-ALL, T-ALL, and BCL11B-activated methylation class samples across four cohorts (Alexander et al, TARGET AML0531, TARGET AML1031, Giacopelli/BeatAML). Boxplots depict the interquartile range (IQR, 25th to 75th percentiles) with central lines indicating median values. Whiskers extend to the most extreme data points that are no more than 1.5 × IQR from the respective quartile boundary. Individual points beyond the whiskers represent outliers. We found that samples inside the BCL11B-activated methylation class show strong expression of BCL11B in all four cohorts.

a. Confusion matrix comparing AML methylation classes (columns) and common genetic alterations (AML). Boxes are colored by genetic alteration and color intensity is relative to abundance of genetic alteration per class. Numbers in boxes show the number of altered samples divided by the number of samples with available information. Statistically significance was determined by Chi-squared test followed by Benjamini-Hochberg adjustment for multiple comparisons to calculate q-values (*q < 0.05,**q < 0.01,***q < 0.001, ****q < 0.0001; see row names). For significantly different mutated genes, post-hoc analysis was performed to assess which methylation classes were differentially mutated. Here, one-sided Fisher's exact test was performed followed by Benjamini-Hochberg adjustment for multiple comparisons to calculate q-values (*q < 0.05,**q < 0.01,***q < 0.001, ****q < 0.0001). b. t-SNE dimensionality reduction of AML classes colored by age groups. AYA, adolescents and young adults. c. Boxplots showing age distribution by methylation class. Whiskers extend to the most extreme data points that are no more than 1.5 × IQR from the respective quartile boundary. Individual points beyond the whiskers represent outliers. d. In the IDH-enriched methylation class, mutations in IDH1 or IDH2 were found in nearly all cases (14/15, 93.3%, also see Extended Data Fig. 3a). However, IDH1 and IDH2 mutations were also found recurrently in several other classes, including HOX-activated AML. Similarly, the Chromatin/spliceosome-enriched methylation class was enriched for mutations in DNMT3A, chromatin regulators and/or spliceosome genes, but these alterations were also recurrently found in several other classes (IDH-enriched, TP53/aneuploidy-enriched, and HOX-activated). Lastly, the TP53/aneuploidy-enriched methylation class had frequent TP53 alterations (22/75, 29.3%) and copy-number changes such as deletions of chromosome 5/5q (24/84, 28.6%) or chromosome 7/7q (31/84, 36.9%). However, this class also contained a significant number of TP53 wild-type cases (53/75, 70.7%) and contained other alterations associated with myelodysplasia-related AML and adverse prognosis, including MECOM rearrangements (9/67, 13.4%) and RUNX1 mutations (18/74, 24.3%). f. t-SNE of AML methylation classes with samples colored by AML with myelodysplasia-related changes (AML-MRC) status according to WHO2016 and whether they are inside or outside of MDS-associated methylation classes. g. a. Chart showing immunophenotyping assessment for 15 acute leukemia samples of the multiplexed retrospective cohort. b. One case (AL_039 diagnosed as AML-MRC) received the highest score for HOX Grp 3 AML, coherent with a TP53-mut and structural alterations involving chromosome 11q23 (harbouring KMT2A). d. a. Line plot shows simulated real-time MARLIN predictions (only scores ≥ 0.8) on the first retrospective acute leukemia cohort (n = 14). One line for the final classification is shown per sample. Line plots show in-silico real-time prediction scores for AL_001 and AL_007 over 72 hours (4,320 minutes). Scores for all methylation classes are shown. Neither sample received a high-confidence prediction score after 72 hours, but both samples briefly reached the threshold at the beginning of sequencing (shortly after 60 minutes). This pattern was not observed in any of the other samples. c. Line plot shows real-time MARLIN prediction for re-sequencing of sample AL_016. Scores for all methylation classes are shown. d. Gating strategy for RTC_001. Raw flow cytometry data were obtained from diagnostic assessment. Total events (368,077 events) were gated using SSC-A and FSC-A to remove debris and doublets. Singlets (236,786 events) were further gated based on SSC-A and the leukocyte common antigen CD45 to identify mature monocytes (SSC-Alow, CD45high), mature lymphocytes (SSC-Ahigh, CD45high) and blasts (SSC-Ahigh, CD45low; 146,427 events). Chart below summarizes immunophenotype results from flow cytometry assessment. e. Protein paint of TP53 mutation detected in RTC_001 by panel sequencing (top) and IGV visualization of TP53 mutation detected using deep nanopore sequencing (bottom). f. Karyotyping results indicate complex copy-number changes and rearrangements. g. Gating strategy for RTC_002. Raw flow cytometry data were obtained from diagnostic assessment. Total events (265,736 events) were gated using SSC-A and FSC-A to remove debris and doublets. Singlets (241,023 events) were further gated based on the myeloid-lineage markers CD14 and CD13 to identify mature lymphocytes (CD14low, CD13low), mature monocytes (CD14high, CD13high) and blasts (CD14low, CD13dim; 219,887 events). Chart below summarizes immunophenotype results from flow cytometry assessment. h. IGV visualization of nanopore reads supporting mutations in TET2 and NPM1, and protein paint of a 51-bp internal tandem duplication affecting FLT3 detected by conventional panel sequencing (bottom left). i. Copy-number profile showing no discernible alterations (top), supporting results obtained by karyotyping (bottom).

a. Timeline for RTC_003 from sample collection to diagnosis using rapid epigenomic classification and conventional diagnostics (top panel). Line graph shows real-time MARLIN prediction scores for the different methylation classes. Dashed horizontal line indicates classification threshold at 0.8 (middle). Copy-number profile generated from nanopore sequencing (bottom). Flow cytometry and aspirate evaluation on day one and day four established an AML diagnosis. Cytogenetic analysis on day two indicated a gain of chromosomes 11 and 13, while gene panel sequencing revealed mutations in ASXL1, ETNK1, IDH1, NRAS, RUNX1, SETBP1 and SRSF2 on day twelve, resulting in a conventional diagnosis of AML with myelodysplasia-related changes. MARLIN briefly reached scores above the confidence threshold for the IDH-enriched AML methylation class, before changing towards the related HOXA/B-activated Group 3 (NPM1, IDH-enriched) methylation class upon deeper sequencing (passing the confidence threshold after 590 minutes). We therefore recommend monitoring real-time MARLIN scores until predictions stabilize. Both classifications were compatible with pathology findings showing AML with myelodysplasia-related mutations, an IDH1 hotspot mutation, and gain of chromosome 11 (harbouring KMT2A), although canonical HOX-associated alterations were not identified. b. Timeline, real-time MARLIN prediction, and copy-number profile for RTC_004. Flow cytometry results on day two showed a mixed phenotype, while aspirate evaluation on day three indicated an ETP-ALL immunophenotype. Gene panel sequencing on day 4 revealed mutations in JAK3 (x2), NOTCH1 (x5) and NRAS. Results from cytogenetics on day 22 revealed a complex karyotype. The final clinical diagnosis was Early T-cell precursor (ETP) lymphoblastic leukemia. In alignment with these results, MARLIN resulted in a high-confidence prediction for HOXA9-activated T-ALL, an ETP-like methylation class, after 50 minutes of sequencing and 96 minutes in total. c. Timeline, real-time MARLIN prediction, and copy-number profile for RTC_005. Flow cytometry on day one and aspirate evaluation on day five established a diagnosis of AML. Gene panel sequencing results on day four revealed mutations in ASXL1, EZH2, NRAS, RUNX1, and ZRSR2. Cytogenetics on day four showed a trisomy 8. The final clinical diagnosis was AML with myelodysplasia-related changes. MARLIN yielded a concordant classification of Chromatin/spliceosome-enriched AML, after 90 minutes of sequencing, and 135 minutes in total.

Title: Structural constraint integration in a generative model for the discovery of quantum materials
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain

Advertisement


Nature Materials

                         (2025)Cite this article


Billions of organic molecules have been computationally generated, yet functional inorganic materials remain scarce due to limited data and structural complexity. Here we introduce Structural Constraint Integration in a GENerative model (SCIGEN), a framework that enforces geometric constraints, such as honeycomb and kagome lattices, within diffusion-based generative models to discover stable quantum materials candidates. SCIGEN enables conditional sampling from the original distribution, preserving output validity while guiding structural motifs. This approach generates ten million inorganic compounds with Archimedean and Lieb lattices, over 10% of which pass multistage stability screening. High-throughput density functional theory calculations on 26,000 candidates shows over 95% convergence and 53% structural stability. A graph neural network classifier detects magnetic ordering in 41% of relaxed structures. Furthermore, we synthesize and characterize two predicted materials, TiPd0.22Bi0.88 and Ti0.5Pd1.5Sb, which display paramagnetic and diamagnetic behaviour, respectively. Our results indicate that SCIGEN provides a scalable path for generating quantum materials guided by lattice geometry.

We have compiled a comprehensive database of AL materials generated by SCIGEN. The dataset provides the folders of all generated materials (10.06 million), the materials that survived after the four-stage prescreening process (1.01 million materials) and DFT-relaxed structures (24,743). The folder with DFT calculation contains materials structures before and after relaxation. The Supplementary Dataset is available from figshare via https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.7283062 (ref. 50.) Source data are provided with this paper.

The source code is available from GitHub via https://github.com/RyotaroOKabe/SCIGEN.

Title: Bryophytes hold a larger gene family space than vascular plants
Description:
